definitions: violation of law, rule, or acceptable behavior
team's attacking strategy and plays in sports
feeling of being insulted or emotionally wounded
examples: The parking offense resulted in a hefty fine
Repeat offenses could lead to license suspension
Their offense scored forty points in the championship game
The coach designed a new offense for the playoffs
She took offense at his thoughtless remark
No offense was intended by the innocent comment

definitions: coordinated military operation to attack enemy positions
organized effort to achieve goals through assertive action
examples: The spring offensive pushed enemy forces back fifty miles
Military planners prepared for a major offensive
The company launched a marketing offensive against competitors
Their charm offensive won over skeptical investors

definitions: proposal to give, sell, or do something for someone
something available that can be accepted or declined
examples: She accepted the job offer without hesitation
The seller rejected our initial offer on the house
Special offers expire at the end of the month
The university increased scholarship offers this year

definitions: gift or sacrifice presented in religious worship or ceremony
products or services made available by a business
shares of stock made available to investors for purchase
examples: The congregation brought offerings to the Sunday service
Ancient peoples made offerings to their gods
The restaurant expanded its vegetarian offerings last month
Their software offerings compete with major tech companies
The initial public offering raised two billion dollars
Investors eagerly awaited the company's stock offering

definitions: room or building where professional or clerical work is conducted
position of authority or responsibility in an organization
professional services provided by lawyers, doctors, or other specialists
examples: Her corner office overlooked the city skyline
Employees returned to the office after remote work
The mayor's office announced new city policies yesterday
She ran for public office three times
The doctor's office called to confirm the appointment
Our law office handles corporate litigation cases

definitions: person who holds an elected or appointed position in government
examples: Current officeholders face challenging reelection campaigns this year
The scandal forced several officeholders to resign immediately
Local officeholders met to discuss budget concerns
Term limits prevent officeholders from serving indefinitely

definitions: member of police force with authority to enforce laws
person holding commissioned rank in armed forces
person holding executive position in a corporation or organization
examples: The police officer directed traffic during the parade
Several officers responded to the emergency call
The naval officer commanded a destroyer squadron
Junior officers received additional training last month
The chief financial officer presented quarterly earnings
Corporate officers met to discuss the merger

definitions: person holding public office or formal position in organization
person who supervises play in sports competitions
examples: Government officials announced the new policy changes
Embassy officials processed visa applications quickly
The official called a foul in the last minute
Game officials reviewed the controversial play

definitions: collective body of officials and bureaucratic systems in government or large organizations
examples: Officialdom moved slowly to address citizen complaints
She navigated officialdom to get necessary permits
Local officialdom resisted the proposed changes
The artist's work criticized corporate officialdom

definitions: act of performing official duties at ceremonies or formal events
act of supervising and enforcing rules in sports competitions
examples: The judge's officiating at weddings supplements her income
His officiating at the ceremony was dignified
Poor officiating affected the game's outcome significantly
The officiating crew faced criticism after controversial calls

definitions: something that counterbalances or compensates for something else
printing method transferring ink from plate to rubber to paper
examples: Carbon offsets help companies reduce environmental impact
Tax credits offset the increased operational costs
The offset printing produced high-quality marketing materials
Modern offset presses can print thousands per hour

definitions: side shoot or branch growing from main stem of plant
something that develops from or derives from something else
examples: The gardener pruned offshoots from the rose bush
New offshoots appeared after spring pruning
The company started as an offshoot of a university research project
Several offshoots of the original movement emerged

definitions: illegal position of player ahead of ball or last defender in various sports
examples: The referee called offside on the striker's goal attempt
Video replay confirmed the player was offside
Understanding offside rules confused new soccer fans
The linesman raised his flag for offside

definitions: child or children of a person, animal, or plant
examples: The couple's offspring all pursued medical careers
Female dolphins care for their offspring for years
The plant's offspring showed interesting genetic variations
Their offspring inherited the family business

definitions: area of theater not visible to audience during performance
examples: Actors waited offstage for their entrance cues
The sound of breaking glass came from offstage
Props were organized offstage before the performance
She practiced her lines offstage during intermission

definitions: large, hideous monster in fairy tales and folklore
person who is cruel, frightening, or unreasonably strict
examples: The ogre in the fairy tale lived under the bridge
Children dressed as ogres for the Halloween party
Her boss was an ogre who terrorized employees
The strict teacher seemed like an ogre to students

definitions: unit of electrical resistance in the International System of Units
examples: The circuit has a resistance of fifty ohms
Engineers measured impedance in ohms
The speaker's impedance rating is eight ohms
Multimeters display resistance values in ohms

definitions: thick, viscous liquid petroleum extracted from underground deposits
liquid fat extracted from plants or animals used in cooking
viscous liquid used to reduce friction between moving parts
examples: Crude oil prices affect global economic markets
The oil spill damaged marine ecosystems extensively
She drizzled olive oil over the salad
Coconut oil solidifies at room temperature
The mechanic changed the engine oil yesterday
Regular oil changes extend vehicle life significantly

definitions: ship designed to transport oil or refuel other vessels
device or person that applies oil to machinery
examples: The naval oiler refueled destroyers at sea
Commercial oilers transport millions of barrels annually
The maintenance worker used an oiler on squeaky hinges
Automatic oilers keep industrial machinery running smoothly

definitions: area of land containing petroleum deposits suitable for commercial extraction
examples: The new oilfield discovery boosted the country's economy
Workers commute to remote oilfields for weeks
Environmental concerns halted oilfield development plans
The oilfield produced millions of barrels annually

definitions: person who owns or works in the oil industry
examples: The Texas oilman invested in renewable energy
Veteran oilmen shared drilling expertise with newcomers
Local oilmen opposed new environmental regulations
The oilman's fortune came from offshore drilling

definitions: smooth, oily preparation applied to skin for medical or cosmetic purposes
examples: The doctor prescribed antibiotic ointment for the wound
She applied healing ointment to the burn
The ointment relieved itching from the rash
Keep the ointment refrigerated after opening

definitions: giraffe-like mammal native to Democratic Republic of Congo with striped legs
examples: The okapi remained unknown to science until 1901
Okapis use their long tongues to strip leaves
The zoo's okapi breeding program proved successful
Wild okapi populations face habitat loss threats

definitions: green seed pod vegetable used in cooking, especially in Southern and African cuisine
examples: She added okra to the gumbo for thickness
Fresh okra appeared at the farmers market
Fried okra is a popular Southern side dish
The okra plants produced abundant pods this season

definitions: collective term for elderly or aged people in society
examples: Programs for the old provide essential social services
The old deserve respect and quality healthcare
Societies must adapt to aging populations
The old share valuable wisdom with younger generations

definitions: evergreen shrub with showy flowers that is highly toxic if ingested
examples: Pink oleanders lined the Mediterranean coastal path
Gardeners wear gloves when pruning oleander bushes
The oleander's toxicity makes it deer-resistant
White oleanders bloomed throughout the summer months

definitions: member of small group holding power, especially wealthy business magnate in certain countries
examples: Russian oligarchs acquired vast fortunes after Soviet collapse
The oligarch's yacht was seized under sanctions
Media oligarchs influence public opinion through ownership
Several oligarchs fled the country amid investigations

definitions: government or control by small group of people, often wealthy or powerful families
examples: The oligarchy controlled national resources for generations
Critics claimed the country had become an oligarchy
Corporate oligarchy threatens democratic principles
The ancient city-state was ruled by oligarchy

definitions: small oval fruit from Mediterranean tree, eaten or pressed for oil
dull yellowish-green color resembling unripe olives
examples: She garnished the martini with green olives
The olive harvest begins in late autumn
The soldier wore olive drab military fatigues
She painted the walls in olive tones

definitions: official appointed to investigate complaints against organizations, especially government agencies
examples: The ombudsman investigated citizens' complaints about city services
Students contacted the university ombudsman about grading disputes
The healthcare ombudsman handles patient grievances independently
Parliament appointed an ombudsman for human rights issues

definitions: twenty-fourth and last letter of the Greek alphabet
final or last element in a series or sequence
examples: Scientists use omega to represent angular velocity
The omega symbol appears in mathematical equations
He considered himself the alpha and omega of the department
The omega point represents ultimate evolutionary convergence

definitions: dish made from beaten eggs cooked and folded, often with filling
examples: She ordered a cheese and mushroom omelette for breakfast
The chef prepared a fluffy French omelette
Making the perfect omelette requires proper heat control
The Spanish omelette contains potatoes and onions

definitions: fifteenth letter of the Greek alphabet, used in mathematics and science
examples: The omicron variant spread rapidly worldwide
Physicists use omicron in certain equations
Omicron represents a small o in Greek
The fraternity's name included omicron

definitions: something left out or excluded from inclusion
failure to do something, especially something legally or morally required
examples: The report's omission of key data raised suspicions
Several omissions in the contract caused disputes
His omission to file taxes resulted in penalties
The omission of safety checks caused the accident

definitions: quality of having unlimited or very great power, traditionally attributed to deities
examples: Religious texts describe God's omnipotence over creation
The dictator's belief in his omnipotence led to downfall
Questions about divine omnipotence puzzle philosophers
No human possesses true omnipotence despite ambitions

definitions: state of knowing everything, traditionally attributed to divine beings
examples: Divine omniscience includes knowledge of all future events
The narrator's omniscience revealed characters' thoughts
Claims of omniscience often prove grossly exaggerated
Omniscience remains a theological and philosophical puzzle

definitions: animal that eats both plants and meat as food sources
examples: Humans are omnivores with varied dietary needs
Bears are omnivores that eat fish and berries
The omnivore's digestive system processes diverse foods
Most primates are omnivores rather than strict herbivores

definitions: medical doctor who specializes in diagnosing and treating cancer
examples: The oncologist recommended chemotherapy for the patient
Pediatric oncologists treat childhood cancers
She consulted three oncologists before deciding treatment
The oncologist explained various treatment options carefully

definitions: branch of medicine dealing with prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of cancer
examples: She specialized in oncology after medical school
The hospital's oncology department has advanced equipment
Recent oncology research shows promising new treatments
Pediatric oncology requires specialized training and compassion

definitions: something that is approaching or advancing toward the observer
examples: The oncoming traffic prevented safe left turns
Drivers must yield to oncoming emergency vehicles
The oncoming storm forced event cancellations
She saw the oncoming train from the platform

definitions: edible bulb with pungent taste and smell, used widely in cooking
examples: Chopping onions made her eyes water terribly
Caramelized onions added sweetness to the dish
Red onions provide color in salads
The recipe calls for two medium onions

definitions: word that phonetically imitates the sound it describes, like buzz or splash
examples: Comic books use onomatopoeia like 'pow' and 'bang'
The word 'sizzle' is an onomatopoeia
Poetry often employs onomatopoeia for sound effects
Children enjoy learning onomatopoeia in language lessons

definitions: beginning or start of something, especially something unpleasant
examples: The onset of winter brought heavy snowfall
Early treatment at symptom onset improves outcomes
The sudden onset of pain required emergency care
Scientists study the onset of various diseases

definitions: fierce or destructive attack, whether physical, verbal, or metaphorical
examples: The army retreated under the enemy's onslaught
The coastal town faced the hurricane's onslaught
The politician weathered an onslaught of criticism
Retailers prepare for the holiday shopping onslaught

definitions: semiprecious stone with parallel bands of different colors, often black and white
examples: The onyx chess set displayed beautiful natural patterns
She wore an antique onyx and silver brooch
Black onyx jewelry remains popular for formal occasions
The bathroom featured onyx countertops and fixtures

definitions: soft mud or slime, especially at bottom of water body
slow escape or discharge of liquid through small openings
examples: Marine biologists studied organisms in ocean floor ooze
The primordial ooze may have harbored early life
Thick ooze seeped from the tree's wounded bark
The wound's ooze required medical attention

definitions: quality of being opaque or not allowing light to pass through
quality of being difficult to understand or lacking transparency
examples: The glass door's opacity provided privacy
Cataracts increase the lens's opacity over time
Corporate opacity frustrated shareholders seeking information
The policy's opacity made compliance difficult

definitions: precious stone displaying iridescent play of colors when light hits it
examples: Australian opals are prized for their fire
The opal ring shimmered with rainbow colors
October's birthstone is the opal
Black opals command the highest prices

definitions: unenclosed or outdoor space available for use
area or opportunity available to all without restriction
examples: Golfers practiced on the open before tournaments
Children played in the open near the school
The job remained open for qualified applicants
The competition is open to all ages

definitions: tool or device used to open containers or packages
first game, act, or item in a series or program
examples: The electric can opener stopped working yesterday
She couldn't find the bottle opener
The season opener attracted record crowds
The comedian served as the opener for the main act
